gflsegpy package¶

Submodules¶

gflsegpy.coord module¶

This module implements the GFL block coordinate descent. This algorithm is slow but returns the exact solution of the GFL.

See [1]_, Algorithm 1.

Basic usage¶

For a basic usage, call gfl_coord() only. It returns the detected change-points of a signal given a maximum number of breakpoints and \(\lambda\) a regularization parameter. Indeed, the greater \(\lambda\), the smaller the number of potential breakpoints. You will have to find a trade-off between a great \(\lambda\) value, that will speed up convergence, and a small \(\lambda\) value that will allow the finding of all breakpoints.

Advanced usage¶

For an advanced usage, you can rely on _gfl_coord() (notice the heading underscore). It returns the optimal GFL coefficients \(\beta \in \mathbb{R}^{(n-1) \times p}\) of a signal given \(\lambda\) a regularization parameter. Then, you will have to extract the change-points from \(\beta\) with a method of your choice.

The function _find_breakpoints() performs such post-processing of \(\beta\). So, as you guess, gfl_coord() simply calls both of the method mentionned above.

Tuning \(\lambda\)¶

The key parameter of the block coordinate descent is \(\lambda\) the regularization coefficient. Before optimizing \(\lambda\), remark that the smaller it is, the greater the number of searched change-points; i.e. the slower the algorithm converges. Then, an appropriate optimisation strategy would consist in testing a sequence \((\lambda_l)_{l=1}^L\) in decreasing order and stopping when the validation error becomes unacceptable or does not drop.

Tuning weights¶

As well as tuning \(\lambda\), you may also want to set the optimal weights of each signal position in the model. This functionality will be added in version 1.1. For now, only the default weights can be used, that are: \(\forall i \in \{1, …, n-1\}, d_i = \sqrt{n \over i (n-i)}\). But, be advised that if you want to detect a single change-point, Bleakley and Vert proved that the default weights are the best ones (see Theorem 3). Else, I cannot give any recommendation. Please, refer to [1]_ and your own experience.

See also

gflsegpy.lars

gflsegpy.coord._find_breakpoints(beta, n=-1, min_step=1, eps=1e-06, verbose=0)[source]¶

Post-processes \(\beta\) the solution of the GFL to find the breakpoints of the corresponding signal. These are the :py:var:`n` successive \(b_k = \arg \max_i \Vert \beta_{i, \bullet} \Vert\) for \(k=1,…,n\).

Parameters:
  • beta (2D-numpy.array) – The GFL coefficients.
  • n (int) – The maximal number of breakpoints to find. If negative, return all.
  • min_step (int) – The minimal step between two breakpoints. E.g. if potential breakpoints are 90, 98 and 100 and min_step=3, the retrieved breakpoints will be 90 and 98.
  • eps (non-negative number) – The threshold at which a float must be regarded as null.
  • verbose (int) – The verbosity level.
Returns:

The breakpoints.
Return type:

numpy.array of int
gflsegpy.coord._gfl_coord(Y, lambda_, max_iter=100, center_Y=True, eps=1e-06, verbose=0)[source]¶

Solves the GFL via a block coordinate descent.

Parameters:
  • Y (numpy.array of shape (n,) or (n, p)) – The signal.
  • lambda (non-negative float) – The Lasso penalty coefficient.
  • max_iter (positive int) – The maximum number of iterations.
  • eps (non-negative number) – The threshold at which a float must be regarded as null.
  • center_Y (bool) – True if \(Y\) has not already been centered (columnwise), else False.
  • verbose (int) – The verbosity level.
Returns:

  • beta (numpy.array of shape (n-1, p)) – The solution of the GFL.
  • KKT (bool) – True if the KKT conditions are verified, else False.
  • niter (int) – The number of performed iterations by the algorithm.
  • U (numpy.array of shape (n, p)) – The reconstructed signal.

See also

_block_coordinate_descent()

gflsegpy.coord.gfl_coord(Y, lambda_, nbpts=-1, min_step=1, max_iter=100, center_Y=True, eps=1e-06, verbose=0)[source]¶

Solves the GFL via a block coordinate descent.

Parameters:
  • Y (1D- or 2D-numpy.array) – The signal.
  • lambda (non-negative float) – The Lasso penalty coefficient.
  • nbpts (int) – The maximum number of breakpoints to find. If negative, return all.
  • min_step (int) – The minimal step between two breakpoints. E.g. if potential breakpoints are 90, 98 and 100 and min_step is 3, retrieved breakpoints will be 90 and 98 in the end.
  • max_iter (positive int) – The maximum number of iterations of the block coordinate descent.
  • eps (non-negative number) – The threshold at which a float must be regarded as null.
  • center_Y (bool) – True if \(Y\) has not already been centered (columnwise), else False.
  • verbose (int) – The verbosity level.
Returns:

The breakpoints indexes.
Return type:

numpy.array of int

See also

_gfl_coord(), _find_breakpoints()

gflsegpy.demo module¶

Usage: python3 -m GFLsegpy.demo [-h] [-B BPTS_TRUE] [-b BPTS_PRED] [-s N P] [-L] [-C] [-l LAMBDA] [-m MIN_STEP] [-I MAX_ITER] [-e EPS] [-v]

This module is a demonstration on gflsegpy on a gaussian random signal.

Optional arguments:
-h, --help show this help message and exit
-B BPTS_TRUE, --bpts_true BPTS_TRUE
 the number of true breakpoints (default: 2)
-b BPTS_PRED, --bpts_pred BPTS_PRED
 the number of breakpoints to find (default: 2)
-s N_SPACE_P, --shape N_SPACE_P
 the shape of the signal (default: (500, 3))
-L, --lars run the LARS
-C, --coorde run the block coordinate descent
-l LAMBDA, --lam LAMBDA
 the \(\lambda\) of the GFL block coordinate descent (default: 10)
-m MIN_STEP, --min_step MIN_STEP
 the minimal step between two predicted breakpoints
-I MAX_ITER, --max_iter MAX_ITER
 the maximum iterations performed by each algorithm (default: 100)
-e EPS, --eps EPS
 the threshold at which a float is considered non-null (default: 1e-6)
-v, --verbose the verbosity level (the more the number of v, the greater the verbosity)

gflsegpy.demo._plot(title, Y, bpts_pred, bpts_true, beta=None, U=None)[source]¶
gflsegpy.demo._signal(shape=(500, 3), nbpts=4)[source]¶

gflsegpy.lars module¶

This module implements the GFL LARS. This algorithm is fast but returns an approximate solution of the group fused Lasso.

Simply call the gflsegpy.gfl_lars() function to use it. In a nutshell, its inputs are the signal and the number of breakpoints to detect, and it returns the estimated breakpoints.

See [1]_, Algorithm 2.

See also

gflsegpy.coord

gflsegpy.lars._find_alpha_min(c_hat, a, A, eps=0)[source]¶

Returns the minimum \(\alpha\) according to line 7, and the corresponding \(\hat{u}\).

For the implementation, the equation at line 7 is reformulated:

\[( \Vert a_{u,\bullet} \Vert^2 - \Vert a_{v,\bullet} \Vert^2 ) \alpha^2 - 2( a_{u,\bullet}^\mathrm{T} \hat{c}_{u,\bullet} - a_{v,\bullet}^\mathrm{T} \hat{c}_{v,\bullet} ) \alpha + ( \Vert \hat{c}_{u,\bullet} \Vert^2 - \Vert \hat{c}_{v,\bullet} \Vert^2 ) = \beta_2 \alpha^2 - 2 \beta_1 \alpha + \beta_0 = 0\]

where \(\beta_0, \beta_1, \beta_2 \in \mathbb{R}\).

gflsegpy.lars._find_alpha_min2(c_hat, a, A, eps=0)[source]¶

Returns the minimum \(\alpha\) according to line 7, and the corresponding \(\hat{u}\).

This function is based upon the authors implementation which does not exactly matches their paper. Indeed, the equation is reformulated:

\[(C - (\Vert a_{u,\bullet} \Vert^2 - \Vert a_{v,\bullet} \Vert^2 )) \alpha^2 - 2(C - (a_{u,\bullet}^\mathrm{T} \hat{c}_{u,\bullet} - a_{v,\bullet}^\mathrm{T} \hat{c}_{v,\bullet} )) \alpha + (C - (\Vert \hat{c}_{u,\bullet} \Vert^2 - \Vert \hat{c}_{v,\bullet} \Vert^2)) = \beta_2 \alpha^2 - 2 \beta_1 \alpha + \beta_0 = 0\]

where \(C = \max_i \Vert \beta_{i, \bullet} \Vert^2\) and \(\beta_0, \beta_1, \beta_2 \in \mathbb{R}\).

gflsegpy.lemmas module¶

This module implements computational lemmas for the GFL. See [1]_, Annexe A.

gflsegpy.lemmas.XbarTR(d, R)[source]¶

See Lemma 5. Speeds up the block coordinate descent.

gflsegpy.lemmas.XbarTXbar(d, A=None, B=None)[source]¶

See Lemma 6. Speeds up the block coordinate descent.

gflsegpy.lemmas.XbarTXbarR(d, R, A=None)[source]¶

See Lemma 7.

Note

As the GFL LARS is not working as expected, this implementation may be reverified.

gflsegpy.lemmas._minmax(a, b)[source]¶

Returns \((\min\{a, b\}, \max\{a, b\})\).

gflsegpy.lemmas.d_weights(n)[source]¶

Returns the best weights scheme for the GFL. See Eq. (5).

gflsegpy.lemmas.invXbarTXbarR(d, R, A=None)[source]¶

See Lemma 8.

Note

As the GFL LARS is not working as expected, this implementation may be reverified.

gflsegpy.plot module¶

This module provides some function to plot the results of the GFL, allowing signal and breakpoints visualization.

gflsegpy.plot._bpts_title(bpts_pred=None, bpts_true=None)[source]¶
gflsegpy.plot.plot_breakpoints(Y, bpts_pred=None, bpts_true=None, beta=None, U=None, max_dim=3)[source]¶

Plots the signal Y and the results of the GFL: the breakpoints, beta the Lasso coefficients and U the reconstructed signal.

Parameters:
  • Y (numpy.array of shape (n, p)) – The signal.
  • bpts_pred (optionnal, 1D-numpy.array of int) – The predicted breakpoints.
  • bpts_true (optionnal, 1D-numpy.array of int) – The true breakpoints.
  • U (optionnal, numpy.array of shape (n, p)) – The multidimensional reconstructed signal.
  • beta (optionnal, numpy.array of shape (n-1, p)) – The GFL coefficients.
  • max_dim (positive int) – The maximum number of dimensions to plot.
Returns:

The matplotlib figure objects used to plot results.
Return type:

list of matplotlib.figure.Figure

Module contents¶

For the attention of users¶

Read this first to avoid wasting time.

The documentation of all functions appears below (public and private), but gflsegpy is very simple to use. By importing gflsegpy, you will be able to call three top-level functions on which you will have to focus as a user:

  • gfl_coord() from gflsegpy.coord;
  • gfl_lars() from gflsegpy.lars;
  • plot_breakpoints() from gflsegpy.plot.

Example

>>> import gflsegpy as seg  # It won't work if you do 'from gflsegpy import *'
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>>
>>> ...  # Processing the signal to segmentate
>>> bpts = seg.gfl_coord(...)  # Perform a block coordinate descent on the signal
>>> ...
>>> bpts = seg.gfl_lars(...)  # Perform the GFL LARS on the signal
>>> ...
>>> seg.plot_breakpoints(...)  # Plot your results
>>> plt.show()  # Show the results
